I do not woo thy presence, INDOLENCE!</br>Goddess, I would not rank</br>A vot'ry in thy train.
I do not ask to wear thy fett'ring flowers,</br>O thou on whose cold lips</br>Faint plays the heartless smile!
Pale, sickly as the unkindly shaded fruit,</br>Thy languid cheek displays</br>No sunny hues of health;
There is no radiance in thy listless eye,</br>No active joy that fires</br>Its sudden glance with life.
I do not wish upon thy downy couch,</br>As in a conscious dream,</br>To doze away the hours,
But, to thy sister LEISURE I would pour</br>The supplicating prayer,</br>And woo her air benign:
Nymph, on whose sunny cheek, the hue of health</br>Blooms like the ruddy fruit</br>Matur'd by Southern rays;
Whose eye beam sparkles to the speaking heart,</br>Like the reflected noon</br>Quick glancing on the waves.
Her would I pray that not for ever thus</br>The ungentle voice of toil</br>Might claim my daily task.
So should my hand a votive temple rear,</br>Through many a distant age,</br>That undestroy'd should stand.
Long should the stately monument proclaim</br>That no ungrateful heart,</br>Goddess!  received thy boon.</br>
